basics.name: Ben Finkelshtein
basics.label: Scientist
basics.summary: PhD candidate at the University of Oxford under the supervision of Prof. Michael Bronstein and Dr. {\.I}smail {\.I}lkan Ceylan. With extensive experience in both academia and industry, I have worked on areas such as natural language processing, anomaly detection, and time series forecasting.

work.name: eBay
work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

work.name: SKF Group, AI Center of Excellence

volunteer.summary: Lead organizer for the New York City branch of the People's Climate March, the largest climate march in history.
highlights: Awarded 'Climate Hero' award by Greenpeace for my efforts organizing the march.
Men of the year 2014 by Time magazine

publications.name: Learning on Large Graphs using Intersecting Communities
publications.summary: A new and fundamentally different pipeline for learning on very large non-sparse graphs using intersecting communities.

publications.name: Graph Neural Network Outputs are Almost Surely Asymptotically Constant
publications.summary: A new angle on the expressive power of GNNs by studying  how the predictions of a GNN probabilistic classifier evolve.

publications.name: Cooperative Graph Neural Networks
publications.summary: A more dynamic and flexible message-passing paradigm in which each node can choose a different communication strategy.

publications.name: Strategic Classification with Graphs Neural Networks
publications.summary: Learning in a setting where users that are dependant can modify their features to obtain favorable predictions.

publications.name: A Simple and Universal Rotation Equivariant Point-cloud Network
publications.summary: A simple architecture which is equivariant to rigid motions with the ability to approximate any equivariant function.

publications.name: Single-Node Attack for Fooling Graph Neural Networks
publications.summary: Showcased that GNNs are vulnerable to a realistic single-node adversarial attack, even when the attacker cannot be chosen.
